candidates.name: Theorem 1: Existence of 3 Disjoint Correspondence Colorings
candidates.statement: For every $K_5$-minor-free graph $G$ and every correspondence 6-cover $	extbf{M}$ of $G$, there exist 3 pairwise disjoint $	extbf{M}$-colorings $\varphi_1, \varphi_2, \varphi_3$ of $G$.
candidates.value: This theorem formalizes the construction of 3 disjoint correspondence colorings for a specific type of graph, which is a direct application of the definition provided in the text.
candidates.formalization_hints: You can use the `color` module in mathlib4 for defining colorings and the `graph` module for handling graphs. Define the correspondence cover and use combinatorial arguments to ensure disjoint colorings.
candidates.abstract_excerpt: Thomassen famously proved that every planar graph is 5-choosable. We explore variants of this result, focusing on finding disjoint correspondence colorings, in the more general class of $K_5$-minor-free graphs. Correspondence colorings generalize list colorings as follows. Given a graph $G$ and a positive integer $t$, a correspondence $t$-cover $\textbf{M}$ assigns to each $v\in V(G)$ a set of allowable colors $\{1_v,\ldots,t_v\}$ and to each edge $vw\in E(G)$ a matching between $\{1_v,\ldots,t_v\}$ and $\{1_w,\ldots,t_w\}$. An $\textbf{M}$-coloring $\varphi$ picks for each vertex $v$ a color $\varphi(v)$ (from the set $\{1_v,\ldots,t_v\}$) such that for each edge $vw\in E(G)$ the colors $\varphi(v),\varphi(w)$ are not matched to each other. Two $\textbf{M}$-colorings $\varphi_1,\varphi_2$ of $G$ are called disjoint if $\varphi_1(v)\ne\varphi_2(v)$ for all $v\in V(G)$. For every $K_5$-minor-free graph $G$ and every correspondence 6-cover $\textbf{M}$ of $G$, we construct 3 pairwise disjoint $\textbf{M}$-colorings $\varphi_1,\varphi_2,\varphi_3$. In contrast, we provide examples of $K_5$-minor-free graphs and correspondence 5-covers $\textbf{M}$ that do not admit 3 disjoint $\textbf{M}$-colorings.

candidates.name: Theorem 2: Non-existence of 3 Disjoint Correspondence Colorings
candidates.statement: We provide examples of $K_5$-minor-free graphs and correspondence 5-covers $	extbf{M}$ that do not admit 3 disjoint $	extbf{M}$-colorings.
candidates.value: This theorem formalizes the negation of the previous theorem, demonstrating that not all $K_5$-minor-free graphs with a specific correspondence cover can be 3-colored disjointly.
candidates.formalization_hints: You can use counterexample constructions to show the non-existence of 3 disjoint colorings. Define the correspondence cover and use combinatorial arguments to prove the non-existence.
candidates.abstract_excerpt: Thomassen famously proved that every planar graph is 5-choosable. We explore variants of this result, focusing on finding disjoint correspondence colorings, in the more general class of $K_5$-minor-free graphs. Correspondence colorings generalize list colorings as follows. Given a graph $G$ and a positive integer $t$, a correspondence $t$-cover $\textbf{M}$ assigns to each $v\in V(G)$ a set of allowable colors $\{1_v,\ldots,t_v\}$ and to each edge $vw\in E(G)$ a matching between $\{1_v,\ldots,t_v\}$ and $\{1_w,\ldots,t_w\}$. An $\textbf{M}$-coloring $\varphi$ picks for each vertex $v$ a color $\varphi(v)$ (from the set $\{1_v,\ldots,t_v\}$) such that for each edge $vw\in E(G)$ the colors $\varphi(v),\varphi(w)$ are not matched to each other. Two $\textbf{M}$-colorings $\varphi_1,\varphi_2$ of $G$ are called disjoint if $\varphi_1(v)\ne\varphi_2(v)$ for all $v\in V(G)$. For every $K_5$-minor-free graph $G$ and every correspondence 6-cover $\textbf{M}$ of $G$, we construct 3 pairwise disjoint $\textbf{M}$-colorings $\varphi_1,\varphi_2,\varphi_3$. In contrast, we provide examples of $K_5$-minor-free graphs and correspondence 5-covers $\textbf{M}$ that do not admit 3 disjoint $\textbf{M}$-colorings.

candidates.name: Comparability of random permutations in the strong Bruhat order
candidates.statement: Given two random permutations, there exists a sequence of adjacent transpositions that each increase the number of inversions by 1, making the permutations comparable in the Bruhat order.
candidates.value: Formalizing this theorem would help in understanding the probabilistic properties of permutations under the strong Bruhat order, which has applications in combinatorics and probability theory.
candidates.formalization_hints: You can use the concept of permutations and transpositions from mathlib4, along with the definition of Bruhat order. Define the probability space and the events where permutations are comparable.

source_paper.title: Comparability of random permutations in the strong Bruhat order

candidates.abstract_excerpt: The (strong) Bruhat order for permutations provides a partial ordering defined as follows: two permutations are comparable if one can be obtained from the other by a sequence of adjacent transpositions that each increase the number of inversions by $1$. Given two random permutations, what is the probability that they are comparable in the Bruhat order? This problem was first considered in a 2006 work of Hammett and Pittel, which showed an exponential lower bound and a polynomial upper bound. The lower bound was very recently improved to the subexponential bound of $\exp(-n^{1/2 + o(1)})$ by Boretsky, Cornejo, Hodges, Horn, Lesnevich, and McAllister. Hammett and Pittel predicted that the probability should decrease polynomially. We show that the probability decreases faster than any polynomial and is on the order of $\exp(-Θ(\log^2 n))$.
